Mayaro virus has been isolated from patient residents in tropical areas of Central and South America, mainly in Brazil, Trinidad and Tobago, Bolivia, Surinam, and Haiti. The virus has also been isolated in French Guiana, Colombia, Panama, and Peru. Detection of antibodies to the virus has been also demonstrated in certain populations of these countries, as well as in Guyana, Colombia, and Peru.
2 Most cases occur in forest workers, who are typically adult males. In the Brazilian Amazon, the specific antibody rate ranges from 5% to 60%; it is higher among closed communities (South American Indians).
